name: Hilltop Hoods
description:
'''Hilltop Hoods''' are an Australian hip hop group that formed in 1994 in [[Blackwood, South Australia|Blackwood]], [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]]. They are regarded as pioneers of the "[[larrikin]]-like" style of [[Australian hip hop]]. The group was founded by [[Suffa]] (Matthew David Lambert) and [[MC Pressure|Pressure]] (Daniel Howe Smith), who were joined by DJ Debris (Barry John M. Francis) after fellow founder, DJ Next (Ben John Hare), left in 1999. The group released its first [[extended play]], ''[[Back Once Again]]'', in 1997 and have subsequently released eight studio albums, two "restrung" remix albums and three [[Extended play|EPs]].

Hilltop Hoods currently hold the record for the most No. 1 albums by an Australian artist or band/group on the [[ARIA Charts|Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA)]] albums chart. Six of their eight studio albums have achieved this feat, they include: ''[[The Hard Road]]'' (2006), ''[[State of the Art (Hilltop Hoods album)|State of the Art]]'' (2009), ''[[Drinking from the Sun]]'' (2012), ''[[Walking Under Stars]]'' (2014), ''[[Drinking from the Sun, Walking Under Stars Restrung]]'' (2016) and ''[[The Great Expanse]]'' (2019). Three tracks have reached the top 10 on the ARIA Singles Chart —"[[Chase That Feeling]]" (2009), "[[I Love It (Hilltop Hoods song)|I Love It]]", featuring [[Sia]] (2011) and "Higher", featuring James Chatburn (2015) — while a further two tracks — "[[Cosby Sweater]]" (2014) and "[[1955 (song)|1955]]" (2016) — reached the top 5. "1955", featuring [[Montaigne (musician)|Montaigne]] & Tom Thum, peaked at number 2 in the Australian charts.

Hilltop Hoods have toured both in Australia and overseas, including playing at music festivals: [[T in the Park]], [[Oxegen]], [[Big Day Out]], [[Clipsal 500]], [[Southbound (festival)|Southbound]], [[The Great Escape (festival)|The Great Escape]], [[Splendour in the Grass]], [[Bassinthegrass]], [[Groovin' the Moo|Groovin' The Moo]], [[Falls Festival]], [[Pyramid Rock Festival]], [[Rollercoaster (Australian festival)|Rollercoaster]], [[Come Together Music Festival|Come Together Festival]] and [[Make Poverty History]].

The band hold the record for the most recurrent artist in the history of the [[Triple J Hottest 100]], with 23 songs voted into the annual countdowns since their first appearance in 2003. At the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2006]] they won "Best Independent Release" and "Best Urban Album" for ''The Hard Road''. In [[ARIA Music Awards of 2007|2007]], they won "Best Urban Album" for their [[remix album]], ''[[The Hard Road: Restrung]]'' (2007). They won the same category in [[ARIA Music Awards of 2009|2009]] for ''State of the Art'' and in [[ARIA Music Awards of 2012|2012]] for ''Drinking from the Sun''. In 2009, Debris also won "[[ARIA Award for Engineer of the Year|Engineer of the Year]]" for his work on ''State of the Art''. The band received their seventh ARIA award in 2014 when ''Walking Under Stars'' won in the Best Urban Album category at the 28th ARIA Awards.
